content.body: Hixie: is http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#dom-window-close intended to be vague on what browsers are allowed to do in non-auxilary cases?
(e.g. show a dialog, or employ heuristics mentioned in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190515#c70)
sayrer: you around?
MikeSmith: hi
hey man
about your message http://www.w3.org/mid/4A3AF8B9.8040700âŠ™mc
ah, yes
you are encouraged to open bugs in the W3C bugzilla
but not reopen them?
there is intentionally no process for it
no, you can reopen them too
oh, I wonder if I just missed the button
it is intended to be a relative free-for-all in that regard
intended by me, I mean, when I set it up for the group
mmm, no, I can't reopen things
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7034
no buttons to do so
hmm, OK
hang on for a couple minutes, I will take a look at it
I can file things
I am pretty sure I can change your individual perms
hope this HTML WG is the right HTML WG
heh
I think we are just using the default bugzilla perms, but anyway, lemme take a look
sayrer: so, to be clear, when you are logged in an go to http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7034
there is no "Reopen bug" radio button
under the Additional Comments textarea?
where should I look?
nope
not there
OK
sayrer: please try again now
tada
I just gave you bugzilla "editbugs" perms. which I guess in bugzilla terms adds you to the editbugs "group"
= "Can edit all aspects of any bug."
now, what I would like to do is have that be the default for all users of our bugzilla
but unfortunately, I reckon that trying to make it so would involve a relatively time-consuming discussion with the powers that be
so I guess for now I will just deal with it case by case
I wish bugzilla allowed those perms to be set per-Product
sayrer: anyway, if you run into w3c bugzilla problems or have questions about our specific instance of it, please feel free to ping me directly and I'll check asap
rather than on public-html, I mean
oh, I wouldn't mail /only/ about bugzilla problems
issue seemed worth raising on the list anyway
yeah, the issue does
I just mean not administrivia-like stuff on public-html
ok
just in the interest of trying to keep traffic volume down on the list
so, about your actual statement in that message, regarding the topic of "content model"
yeah
"I can see why this might be tempting to specify for theoretical reasons, but I can't think of a use case."
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/images/content-venn.svg
why does that exist?
oh, that
there's also this business of forming outlines
it's not clear from you message that that's what you meant
that is the first illustration under "3.4 Content models"
"There are also certain elements that are sectioning roots. These are distinct from sectioning content, but they can also have an outline."
yeah, I thought you had brought that up before -- the question of the appropriateness of the outline algorithm, I mean
like... what is this...
well, I'm sure whoever answered it thought they did a good job addressing the issue
I should pay more attention
sayrer: I think the term "sectioning roots" is Hixie coining a language primitives that he needs to reference in multiple definitions elsewhere
I think "sectioning content" is fairly unambiguous
or at least a familiar concept
sayrer: anyway, I would personally advise/prefer that you raise those kinds of questions individual bugzilla issues -- if/when you have time
hmm yeah

in some cases it might be useful to post them directly to public-html too, but I have the bugzilla set up so that an automated notification gets sent to the list each time any bug is first opened or resolved
so that way, people who are actually interested enough to want to take time to follow the discussion further can take time to cc themselves to the bugzilla issue
gtg
"Font family names containing more than one word should be quoted." - i've never understood why it should be quoted
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-fonts-20090618/
MikeSmith: I have sympathy with sayrer's position (I am not sure authoring conformance requirements are actually useful) but I think his bug report is ridiculous and insulting
MikeSmith: and should be closed
MikeSmith: snark and sarcasm are not appropriate ways to express differences of opinion in a bug tracker
othermaciej: well, I'm the one who raised it initially, with that summary (though in jest)
I have learned my lesson
MikeSmith: in that case - I think your bug report is not an appropriate way to raise an issue
gsnedders: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090618#l-356
MikeSmith: I think it should be closed and you and/or Rob should raise sincere issues
such as "HTML5 should have no authoring conformance requirements"
or suggesting specific changes to the authoring conformance requirements

it's not clear to me which the bug is really asking for - I think it's obvious that literally replacing the text "conformance checker" with "loyalty checker" everywhere is not something anyone sincerely wants
i think the requirements are very useful for authors
othermaciej: yeah, of course
othermaciej: but I will let Rob do what he wants we the issue, and let anybody else who uses bugzilla do anything they want with it
since I haven't used the bug tracker much, I don't feel it's my place to close it
I am not going to let that bugzilla become yet another place where we get mired in discussions about what's appropriate and what the process should be
isn't the bug closed already?
but if someone filed a bug like that in WebKit bugzilla, it would be INVALID city, and if people tried to reopen it, they would get a talking to about responsible use of bugzilla
zcorpan_: I closed it, but Rob said he wanted to reopen it, and I said, go ahead
othermaciej: our bugzilla is relatively lightly used now -- nothing on the scale of Webkit bugzilla -- and we do not have a general problem
if this develops in a bigger problem, then I will do something about it
sure, but filing sarcastic bug reports and reopening them are still abusive things to do
you in particular should set a better example
othermaciej: add it to the list of many other things in the group that are considered abusive by some members of the group
othermaciej: christ
I hope you mean that "you in particular should set a better example" sarcastically
I can't tell
fine, I don't want to get mired in a postmodern discussion of whether courtesy is an illusion
good
I don't want to either
but please, seriously, don't schoolmarm me with "you in particular should set a better example" nonsense
I get plenty enough of that already
believe me
i wonder why jd doesn't put quotes around ECMAScript 4
zcorpan_: because he's not afraid of ECMAScript 4
he only uses scare quotes to indicate stuff that he's afraid of
they were scare quotes of disdain
ECMAScript 4 was based on ActionScript so it would be hard for him to consistently disdain it
(ES4 also had a lot more hype than reality, somewhat undermining his point...)
the comments here are entertaining: http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=662620
entertaining, or insulting?
both!
regarding the bug report: I did not file it, but I do think it raises a real issue
and the title is only insulting to the extent that it is poignant
sayrer: I think a sincere bug that  suggests removing conformance requirements would be useful
there is no swearing or personal attacks
or a bug that suggested specific changes to removing conformance requirements
so I think politeness police kind of stuff is bikeshedding
I think sarcastically requesting a change that is not what is actually desired, without making it clear what is desired, is a bad use of the bug tracker
filing the bug in the first place could be seen as comedy, reopening it is abusive
yes, I think your point, while possibly valid, is unimportant
reopening the bug is not abusive
sayrer: I agree with othermaciej that we would be better off if you changed the title of the bug
I went and asked for permision to reopen it from the person who filed it
chain reopening sarcastic bugs is a waste of people's time, and not likely to lead to any productive outcome
sayrer: I mean better off in that if you actually want people to take the issue seriously
Larry and Maciej seem to want to change the title... I don't care what it is
sayrer: if you don't care what it is, I will go ahead and change it
go for it
of course, now it's been defaced by maciej lecturing :)
I think my point was valid, and if it was unimportant, then surely debating its unimportance is an even greater waste of time

I have re-learnedd the lesson that attempts at humor are most successful among a group of people who are reasonably familiar with each, but less successful in a group a people who have a tendency to be distrustful of each others and who are prone to suspect (or even openly accuse) each other of having ulterior motives
(reasonably familiar with each other)

MikeSmith: I get that you were trying to be funny, and I don't want to say humor in a bug tracker is always wrong, it's just that mixing it up with a substantive issue of controversy and combined with reopening it starts to be less funny
yep, point taken
I regret being heavy-handed in my complaining about it
othermaciej: np. I regret having filed it as bug to begin with
wonders why http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-fonts-20090618/ refers to "XHTML headings" rather than "HTML headings"
jruderman: send mail, sorry can't reply right now
i wonder if 'unicode-range' is a good feature to have
does anyone implement it?
if an author wants to optimize bandwidth, it seems Philip`'s approach is more effective
i mean, in the example, a 4.5 MB font is downloaded just to render an arrow
"Matching occurs in a well-defined order to insure ..."
Hixie, are you happy with the statement in html5 about document.all booleanifying to false remaining there? or do you think it needs to web idl?
i suppose whatever spec defines style.filter needs it
then again, it's just one sentence of prose, so it's not that much of a burden to really need an [Undetectable] in web idl
updates https://developer.mozilla.org/En/Using_audio_and_video_in_Firefox to use <object> instead of <applet>
heycam: typeof document.all should return 'undefined', iirc
zcorpan_, ah. at least that's within the realms of conformance to the ecmascript spec.
i suppose Hixie should add that then (as long as [Undetectable] isn't in web idl)
heycam: i've no idea. i couldn't get browser vendors to tell me anything useful.
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/146
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/147 - firefox false, webkit and opera true
do instanceof doesn't seem to need anything special
but typeof does
firefox stringifies to 'undefined' too, but opera and webkit don't
it seems firefox tries to make it as undetectable as possible, while opera and webkit try to do as little as necessary to be compatible with web content
I can tell you guys what we do to make document.all undetectable
it's more than just the typeof thing
does HTML5 intend to spec document.all?
(I couldn't find it in the IDL but maybe it's spec'd elsewhere?)
it does spec it already
othermaciej: you can reply to my email on public-html :)
zcorpan_: i did the reverse engineering; the question was what was actually needed and what were browser vendors willing to change to doing
the HTMLDocument interface definition doesn't seem to list an "all" property
where is it spec'd?
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/the-xhtml-syntax.html#dom-document-all
Hixie: someone at opera said typeof was required for web compat
I see
splitting the interfaces is a bit unwieldy
though I can understand it as a way to hide the bad stuff
Hixie: maybe you should include the obsolete stuff together with the other things but hide it behind class=impl (and have // obsolete in the IDL)?
although i guess having it in a separate section is better for authors and implementors will see the obsolete section anyway
zcorpan_: It'd be great if someone made a font format that could just download the glyphs that were needed on demand, so you wouldn't have to download the entire font or subset it in advance
Philip`: indeed
but it seems everyone wants to invent new formats to add DRM capabilities, not to add any actually useful features
Hixie, did you in the end need something from Web IDL for the split window "this" issue?
Philip`: still, 'unicode-range' is not it
i.e. where "this" means the WindowProxy instead of the Window?
heycam: no
ok cool
is going through some old notes
heycam: search HTML5 for WindowProxy if you want to see how i ended up doing it
should get better at quoting the spec in his spec feedback emails
I sent what I think is an exhaustive list of what we do
zcorpan_: I'm an implementor and I didn't see it til it was pointed out
though I guess I will know to look for them now
Hixie: maybe you should have // further members are specified xref in the main IDL
zcorpan_: that's a good idea; file a bug for me?
basically what we do is make sure document.all compares as false in boolean comparisons, has a type of "undefined", and compares equal to undefined, null and false
(bot not strict equal)
othermaciej: i saw all kinds of weird per-op-code behaviour when i was looking at jsc
Hixie: I believe all of that behavior implements what I described above and nothing more
I may have missed a spot
but I don't think so
cool
opera doesn't do the equals thing it seems
I believe we apply the exact same set of hacks to style.filter
Hixie, at one point you asked about an open issues list for Web IDL. That list should just be the red notes in the spec, now.
heycam: cool
heycam: good to know
so if there is something you requested that hasn't been handled but doesn't have a red note, let me know
roger
(btw I should note that, at least for us, undetectability belongs to the object implementing document.all, not to the property)
(so if you do var failAPI = document.all, then failAPI will have all the same forms of undetectability)
that's the same in opera i think
I think Mozilla does something elaborate and weird that may be specific to the context of an if statement
not sure how to define that things are == null and == undefined
but i'm sure i'll figure out a way
what's hard about it?
Hixie: opera doesn't do that, so it might not be needed for compat
can't you just literally list some of the ECMAScript expressions that MUST evaluate to certain values, despite what the ES spec says for normal objects?
i don't know
i'm not really sure how to define the expression
I can't remember if we did it for consistency or because we thought some sites really check that way
is |document.all == foo| true if |foo === null|?
if (document.all != undefined) seems like a plausible check
that's the case in WebKit
what about things like isNaN, and |'all' in document|, and so on?
it does it based on the value being null, the expression doesn't have to contain the null literall
so is it a property of the == operator or of the document.all object?
or both?
or something else?
anyway like i said i'm sure i'll find a way to express it
alert('all' in document) reports true in Safari
i just haven't look at it in detail yet
it's a property of the combination of the object and the == operator
so if there is some other language mechanism to do comparisons, then it isn't affected by this magic?
and if, say, JS added operator overloading, an overloaded '==' wouldn't see magic?
there is the === operator
which is not affected
basically my point is just that the wording has to be very carefully thought out; i don't think it'll be especially hard or anything
I can't predict how it would interact with hypothetical future features
if (document.all === undefined) seems like an equally plausible check as if (document.all == undefined), although i guess would be a lot less common
ideally if we define it clearly (i.e. not by example), it will be well-defined
hmmm
I can't find signs of document.all existing at all in Firefox
othermaciej: try quirks mode
does the page need to have some special property for document.all to appear even in hidden form?
has to be in quirks mode in firefox
oh hey, google.com has  a docype now
i'm trying :-)
there goes my favorite quirks mode test page!
my influence is slow, but non-zero :-)
jens meiert has been helping a lot too
he even set up an internal instance of henri's validator
doesn't validate though :(
not yet :-)
google.com is an impressively deceptive page in that while it looks simple, it is insanely complicated
Firefox makes document.all == to undefined and null
which is probably why we did that
so many domains, so many languages, so many locales, so many things to expose differently in different countries...
is waiting for Hixie to respond to emails from 2005 where people ask Hixie to make google.com front page validate
i doubt i have those around still
oh did i mention that the web elements guys fixed the problems ou raised?
or were going to, anyway?
dunno if they actually did
let me know in a few months if you still find them broken
cool
they apparently were already intending to do it
and had introduced a bunch of errors at the last minute trying to fix things up in other browsers
Woah, Chrome can run Canvex almost full-screen with almost acceptable performance :-o
(Maybe other modern browsers can too, but I've not tried them)
I need to work on it again to make it slower
zcorpan_: Send email. I probably won't get around to doing anything about it till in Sweden anyway though. :)
zcorpan_: What's wrong about the output?
JohnResig, yt?
JohnResig, I wanted to discuss getting the selectors api test suite completed, as mentioned in my last mail to public-webapps
gsnedders: the h2s should be sub sections of the h1
remembers the header/hgroup change. that's the bug :P
http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/gallery/2009/jun/18/mps-expenses-houseofcommons?picture=349036998 - noooo! Comic Sans :-(
Philip`: download glyphs on demand? that's crazy talk
hmm
why is jd proud of the fact that Flash only checks for updates once a month?
thinks jd is best ignored at this point
who's jd?
http://blogs.adobe.com/jd/
Lachy: "IE lacks support for many of the CSS3 selectors tested in the test suite, but to be fair, these failure should be ignored.
that's bullshit :-(
do we really have to remove those tests?
ok, hang on, I should probably keep reading
JohnResig: Is CSS 3 selectors really need to be a prerequisite for the selectors test suite, though?
gsnedders: for a fully interoperable implementation, yep!
JohnResig: How so? What in selectors requires CSS 3 selectors to be tested?

gsnedders: I'm saying that if we care about having interoperability - and making sure that all of the possible selectors work correctly - we need to test the full gamut of CSS selectors. A number of bugs were caught in the implementations of WebKit, Firefox and Opera since these tests existed - stripping them out will mean 1) There will be regressions 2) That IE will implement more bugs in their implementation and 3) That the implementations will be more li
JohnResig: Is that not an issue for the CSS 3 selectors test suite, though?
gsnedders: no - it's simply assumed that ass CSS selectors work identically as they do in the browser - it's very likely that they don't
gsnedders, that test suite does not test them in the context of the Selectors API
there were a number of selectors that failed in the suite but "passed" in the official CSS selector test suite
JohnResig, no, I didn't say we should remove them.
Lachy: heh, ok, I'm still reading
Lachy: just got a little flustered ;)
Just that counting them when working out IE's level of conformance isn't really fair, because not supporting CSS3 doesn't affect their conformance with the requirements in Selectors API
would nevertheless argue that unless the Selectors API requires support for CSS 3 Selectors (normatively) its test suite should just check against CSS 2.1, and optionally CSS 3 Selectors
Lachy: I see, yeah - and the fact that there's been 3 nearly-conformant implementations (as you pointed out) kind of removes the need for IE to be fully conformant
regardless
Lachy: I'm reading over the list on the bottom now
roc: Why so crazy? It's just like downloading seekable media resources, except with lots more seeking, so you could add some kind of batching, and then it'd be trivial! :-)
Lachy: the test suite was actually, originally, xhtml - and included SVG inside of it
Lachy: I removed it because it broke in IE and we wanted the suite to run in IE :-/

as far as selectors api conformance is concerned, for interoperability, we only need to ensure that the selectors that the implementations do support work correctly in the API. Requiring that they also work with Selectors that the implementation don't even claim support is silly
ok. In that case, it's probably easiest to just make a new version that tests XHTML/SVG specific stuff
the first batch of hixie tests are pretty painless
woah, Hixie's 002-001 test is pretty nuts
do you mean checking for "[object NodeList]"
Lachy: yeah - checking that the resulting NodeList is == to "[object NodeList]"
I'm fine wil leaving the whole of Hixie's 002 tests out
Lachy: we already test for 002-003
and isn't 002-002 part of a different spec?
ok, anyway, I'll merge in 001
well, the IDL says NoInterfaceObject
so technically, 002-002 is testing a selectors api requirement, though it depends on a relatively unstable spec
